page.title: International media reaction to Barack Obama's 2008 election

rev.comment: Fair use images removed. You are not permitted to display them in userspace, regardless of prep status of the article.
rev.diff:
Line 1: Line 1:
{{Userspace draft|source=ArticleWizard|date=January 2010}}
{{Userspace draft|source=ArticleWizard|date=January 2010}}
â
[[File:The Age Front Nov 6 2008.jpg|thumb|The cover of Australia's ''[[The Age]]'' newspaper the day after Obama was elected in November, 2008.]]
+
<!--[[File:The Age Front Nov 6 2008.jpg|thumb|The cover of Australia's ''[[The Age]]'' newspaper the day after Obama was elected in November, 2008.]]-->
When [[Barack Obama]] won the [[United States presidential election, 2008]] media around the world reacted with strong emotions. Most expressed positive hopes and expecations for the president-elect, but some tried to prepare their readers for disappointment. Editorials varied from elation to cautious optimism, and a few were outright skeptical. Many celebrated Obama's victory as historic and a sign of changing race-relations in America. Many commentators said the election results surprised them because there was an international perception that America was too racist to elect a black president. Many also said people in their country were blinded by infatuation with Obama and encouraged them to see him as a normal human being capable of error. Within a week, the excitement and elation subsided somewhat and many newspaper editorials began to caution that Obama had enormous obstacles ahead.
When [[Barack Obama]] won the [[United States presidential election, 2008]] media around the world reacted with strong emotions. Most expressed positive hopes and expecations for the president-elect, but some tried to prepare their readers for disappointment. Editorials varied from elation to cautious optimism, and a few were outright skeptical. Many celebrated Obama's victory as historic and a sign of changing race-relations in America. Many commentators said the election results surprised them because there was an international perception that America was too racist to elect a black president. Many also said people in their country were blinded by infatuation with Obama and encouraged them to see him as a normal human being capable of error. Within a week, the excitement and elation subsided somewhat and many newspaper editorials began to caution that Obama had enormous obstacles ahead.
Line 7: Line 7:
== Elation ==
== Elation ==
â
[[File:Liberation_front_Nov_6_2008.jpgâ|thumb|left|The cover of France's ''[[LibÃ©ration]]'' daily newspaper the day after Obama was elected in November, 2008, which reads "An American Dream."]]<!--Non free image removed by DASHBot-->
+
<!--[[File:Liberation_front_Nov_6_2008.jpgâ|thumb|left|The cover of France's ''[[LibÃ©ration]]'' daily newspaper the day after Obama was elected in November, 2008, which reads "An American Dream."]]--><!--Non free image removed by DASHBot-->
Pre-election polls showed people around the world preferred candidate Obama to his opponent, Sen. John McCain, because they expected relations between the U.S. and the rest of the world to improve if Senator Obama won.<ref>September 9, 2008 [http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2008/09/09/2360240.htm?section=world World wants Obama as president: poll]</ref> Unusual for an American politician, Obama had become a worldwide celebrity before his election. He had travelled to Europe, and spoke to a crowd of 100,000 in [[Berlin]] in July 2008, before he was nominated the Democratic candidate. His youth (47 years old), good looks, intellectual accuity, charm and oratory skills had already impressed many non-Americans<ref>July 24, 2008 [http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/0,1518,567926,00.html German Politicians react to Obama's speech]</ref>. This had created an infatuation with the candidate abroad.
Pre-election polls showed people around the world preferred candidate Obama to his opponent, Sen. John McCain, because they expected relations between the U.S. and the rest of the world to improve if Senator Obama won.<ref>September 9, 2008 [http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2008/09/09/2360240.htm?section=world World wants Obama as president: poll]</ref> Unusual for an American politician, Obama had become a worldwide celebrity before his election. He had travelled to Europe, and spoke to a crowd of 100,000 in [[Berlin]] in July 2008, before he was nominated the Democratic candidate. His youth (47 years old), good looks, intellectual accuity, charm and oratory skills had already impressed many non-Americans<ref>July 24, 2008 [http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/0,1518,567926,00.html German Politicians react to Obama's speech]</ref>. This had created an infatuation with the candidate abroad.
Line 19: Line 19:
== Cautious optimism ==
== Cautious optimism ==
â
[[File:Rzeczpospolita cover Nov. 5 2008.jpg|thumb|The cover of Polish newspaper ''[[Rzeczpospolita]]'' on the day after Obama's 2008 election, which reads "America Chose."]]
+
<!--[[File:Rzeczpospolita cover Nov. 5 2008.jpg|thumb|The cover of Polish newspaper ''[[Rzeczpospolita]]'' on the day after Obama's 2008 election, which reads "America Chose."]]-->
After Obama's election, commentators were inclined to celebrate, but cautioned readers to not set their expectations too high for the new president-elect. Meidyatama Suryodiningrat, writing for the ''[[The Jakarta Post]]'' said, "Indonesians are just as enamored as the rest of the world. It is an upsurge fueled by sentimentality over rationality." <ref>November 5, 2008 [http://worldmeets.us/thejakartapost000006.shtml Obama Not All He's Cracked Up to Be]</ref>Vedomosti said, "Obama will have to confront so many outstanding challenges that he is not to be envied." <ref>November 6, 2008 [http://worldmeets.us/vedomosti000001.shtml Obama: The Color of Change for Both Russia and Europe]</ref> An editorial by [[Pierre Haski]] for ''[[Rue 89]]'' in France said Obama "united an even greater majority of the world's citizens who 'voted' for him in spirit" but remarked that his expectations and challenges were enormous:
After Obama's election, commentators were inclined to celebrate, but cautioned readers to not set their expectations too high for the new president-elect. Meidyatama Suryodiningrat, writing for the ''[[The Jakarta Post]]'' said, "Indonesians are just as enamored as the rest of the world. It is an upsurge fueled by sentimentality over rationality." <ref>November 5, 2008 [http://worldmeets.us/thejakartapost000006.shtml Obama Not All He's Cracked Up to Be]</ref>Vedomosti said, "Obama will have to confront so many outstanding challenges that he is not to be envied." <ref>November 6, 2008 [http://worldmeets.us/vedomosti000001.shtml Obama: The Color of Change for Both Russia and Europe]</ref> An editorial by [[Pierre Haski]] for ''[[Rue 89]]'' in France said Obama "united an even greater majority of the world's citizens who 'voted' for him in spirit" but remarked that his expectations and challenges were enormous:
Line 37: Line 37:
== Reflections on race ==
== Reflections on race ==
â
[[File:Eldiario de yaracuay front Nov 5 2008.jpg|thumb|The cover of ''El Diario de Yaracuy'' in Venezuela on the morning after Obama's November, 2008 election to U.S. president, which reads "Obama wins 51 percent of the vote."]]
+
<!--[[File:Eldiario de yaracuay front Nov 5 2008.jpg|thumb|The cover of ''El Diario de Yaracuy'' in Venezuela on the morning after Obama's November, 2008 election to U.S. president, which reads "Obama wins 51 percent of the vote."]]-->
Many publications used Obama's election to reflect on their country's own race relations or to comment on America's. An editorial in Russia's ''[[Vedomosti]]'' business daily did not praise Obama, but focused instead America's ability to elect a black man in contrast with Russia's inability to elect someone from an ethnic minority.<ref>November 6, 2008 [http://worldmeets.us/vedomosti000001.shtml Obama: The Color of Change for Both Russia and Europe]</ref>
Many publications used Obama's election to reflect on their country's own race relations or to comment on America's. An editorial in Russia's ''[[Vedomosti]]'' business daily did not praise Obama, but focused instead America's ability to elect a black man in contrast with Russia's inability to elect someone from an ethnic minority.<ref>November 6, 2008 [http://worldmeets.us/vedomosti000001.shtml Obama: The Color of Change for Both Russia and Europe]</ref>
<blockquote>
<blockquote>
Line 52: Line 52:
== Reflections on internal politics ==
== Reflections on internal politics ==
â
[[File:Toronto Star front Nov 5 2008.jpg|thumb|left|The front page of the ''[[Toronto Star]]'' after Barack Obama's 2008 election.]]
+
<!--[[File:Toronto Star front Nov 5 2008.jpg|thumb|left|The front page of the ''[[Toronto Star]]'' after Barack Obama's 2008 election.]]-->
Laurent Joffrin, writing for [[LibÃ©ration]], hoped Obama's victory would reinvigorate Europe's left: "Progressives had the idea of progress stolen from them. Now they have taken it back. What a lesson for the European left, which has been weakened, has no real plans and, above all, lacks a new ideal!"<ref>November 6, 2008 [http://worldmeets.us/liberation000121.shtml Why Obama's Victory is 'Decisive to Our Fate']</ref>''[[Le Monde]]'' wrote that the "Obama phenomenon" could serve as an example to all French political parties.<ref>November 6, 2008 [http://worldmeets.us/lemonde0000188.shtml French Parties 'All Draw Inspiration' from Obama Win]</ref>At ''[[Le Figaro]]'', an editorial by Paul-Henri du Limbert said the French could "learn a lesson" from Obama's election. "We reproached â[[Sarkozy]] the Americanâ for loving the country, its values and its way of life, but today we have realized that this wasn't such a terrible lack of good taste."<ref>November 6, 2008 [http://worldmeets.us/lefigaro0000249.shtml Obama's Lesson to the French]</ref>[[Magdalena Åroda]], writing for Poland's [[Gazeta Wyborcza]], said she envied Americans their Obama: "I envy Americans their political engagement, which doesn't exhaust itself with the act of voting or posting election fliers. Americans debate, go door to door and travel to different states in order to convert others to their point of view. This is how a political culture is born and a capital of social trust is established, which, irrespective of who wins the election, remains an important national asset - a thing Poland still painfully lacks."
Laurent Joffrin, writing for [[LibÃ©ration]], hoped Obama's victory would reinvigorate Europe's left: "Progressives had the idea of progress stolen from them. Now they have taken it back. What a lesson for the European left, which has been weakened, has no real plans and, above all, lacks a new ideal!"<ref>November 6, 2008 [http://worldmeets.us/liberation000121.shtml Why Obama's Victory is 'Decisive to Our Fate']</ref>''[[Le Monde]]'' wrote that the "Obama phenomenon" could serve as an example to all French political parties.<ref>November 6, 2008 [http://worldmeets.us/lemonde0000188.shtml French Parties 'All Draw Inspiration' from Obama Win]</ref>At ''[[Le Figaro]]'', an editorial by Paul-Henri du Limbert said the French could "learn a lesson" from Obama's election. Americans debate, go door to door and travel to different states in order to convert others to their point of view. This is how a political culture is born and a capital of social trust is established, which, irrespective of who wins the election, remains an important national asset - a thing Poland still painfully lacks."
<ref>November 6, 2008 [http://worldmeets.us/gazetawyborcza000019.shtml 'Why I Envy Americans Their Obama']</ref>In an online discussion at ''[[The Indian Express]]'', an unkown writer and commenters debated whether India could have its own Obama:

Line 61: Line 61:
== Reflections on President Bush ==
== Reflections on President Bush ==
â
[[File:Sidney Morning Herald front Nov 6 2008 jpg.jpg|thumb|The front page of the ''[[Sydney Morning Herald]]'' after Barack Obama's 2008 election.]]
+
<!--[[File:Sidney Morning Herald front Nov 6 2008 jpg.jpg|thumb|The front page of the ''[[Sydney Morning Herald]]'' after Barack Obama's 2008 election.]]-->
[[President George W. Bush]] had been criticized in America and abroad for his foreign policies, including his decisions to invade Iraq and Afghanistan during his eight years in office. After the 2008 election, many international editorials and commentators expressed hope that the new administration would provide a break from the previous administration's foreign policy choices.
[[President George W. Bush]] had been criticized in America and abroad for his foreign policies, including his decisions to invade Iraq and Afghanistan during his eight years in office. After the 2008 election, many international editorials and commentators expressed hope that the new administration would provide a break from the previous administration's foreign policy choices.
